Q. How will it protect against natural disasters?
A. We're investing $50B to protect our infrastructure from extreme weather. We know that the dramatic increase in extreme weather events is due in large part to climate change & everything in this bill is aimed at addressing it.

Q. How will it help my people like my 81-year-old mother with heating costs?
A. This law includes $$ for energy & cost-saving programs, like $3.5B for the Weatherization Assistance Program, which helps families protect their homes against weather & optimize energy efficiency.

Q. Will this bill expand internet access?
A. Yes! MA will receive at least $100M to provide broadband coverage across the state and 19% of people in our state will be eligible for a new benefit that will help low-income families afford internet access.

Q. What provisions in the law will increase the ability for people to charge their EV?
A: The #InfrastructureLaw includes $7.5B to build a national network of EV chargers to facilitate long-distance travel and provide convenient charging options. MA will receive $63 million! üöò

Q. How will the law address lead pipes & PFAS?
A: The law provides $55B to ensure clean, safe drinking water is a right in all communities:
-$15B to boost lead pipe remediation efforts around the country

Today, of the original 69 tribes that made up the Wampanoag Nation, only 3 survive, including the Mashpee Wampanoag. 

These Tribes add so much to the Commonwealth's culture and help us to speak truth about our past and celebrate the gift of our natural surroundings. (6/7)

For the Wampanoag, after numerous treaty violations and colonist-induced epidemics, their population had declined by as much as 90%. Frustrated by their loss of land and people, the Wampanoag fought back resulting in King Philip‚Äôs War. (5/7)

Massachusetts lived in Greater Boston. Unprepared early European settlers oft raided them for supplies & forcibly took most of their land. This resulted in severe poverty and population decline. (4/7)

Here long before the Pilgrims, the Wampanoag Nation's ancestral lands extends from Rhode Island, Cape Cod and southern MA. It was the Wampanoag who taught the Pilgrims how to hunt & plant crops, saving them from starvation and leading to the #Thanksgiving myth. (3/7)

2 Indigenous nations have laid claim to the lands around #MA5. The Massachusett, who's name means ‚ÄúAt the Great Hill" ‚Äî and who our state is named after ‚Äî and the Wampanoag, whose name means ‚ÄúPeople of the First Light‚Äù. (2/7)
